metadata.case_name: Appellant (Defendant No. 1) v. Respondents Nos. 1 and 2 (Heirs of Original Plaintiff) and Respondent No. 3 (Defendant No. 2)

facts.text: Bhagirathibai, wife of Shivagonda Patil and Navwali warchi Vatandar of Police Patil family, died in 1936. Plaintiff acquired heirship-ownership over suit properties as near heir.
Suit properties were in possession of defendant No. 2 without right.
Original plaintiff filed Suit No. 3/1942 against defendant No. 2 (Pirgonda Annappa) for declaration of ownership and possession of suit properties.
Decree in ejectment obtained on March 28, 1944, confirmed in appeal on July 9, 1945, and affirmed by Supreme Court of Kolhapur on April 2, 1946.
Original plaintiff applied for execution of decree but resisted by appellant (defendant No. 1).
Application under O. XXI, r. 97 CPC complaining of resistance, dismissed under O. XXI, r. 99 on April 12, 1947.
Original plaintiff instituted suit (Civil Suit No. 23/1949) under O. XXI, r. 103 CPC on March 12, 1948, against appellant (defendant No. 1) and defendant No. 2 for declaration of right to possession.

Plaint prior to amendment stated defendant No. 2 in collusion with defendant No. 1 caused objection; plaintiff conducted misc. suit No. 5/1946 which was decided against him; no particular averments of title against appellant.
Appellant filed application on November 20, 1948, pointing out plaint based on decree to which appellant not party, no ownership shown against him, sought no permission for amendment.
Plaintiff's pleader noted suit under O. XXI, r. 103 CPC, grant relief as per provision.
Appellant filed written statement on December 20, 1949, objecting suit not maintainable, no cause of action against him.
Preliminary issue framed on January 19, 1950: whether suit tenable against appellant.

Plaintiff applied on March 29, 1950, to amend plaint by inserting para 1A detailing title from Bhagirathibai's death, heirship, prior suit decree, and sentences in para 3 that defendant No. 1 from Mulki Patil family has nothing to do with suit property.
Civil Judge, Senior Division, Kolhapur rejected amendment and dismissed suit on March 31, 1950, as no title case against defendant No. 1 who was not party to earlier suit.
Appeal to Bombay High Court (Appeal No. 496 of 1950), allowed amendment on September 6, 1951, subject to costs.
Appellant obtained special leave; present appeal filed.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court was wrong in allowing amendment of the plaint at appellate stage in circumstances where limitation for suit under O. XXI, r. 103 CPC had expired and defect pointed out earlier.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in allowing amendment at late stage despite power to do so; limitation expired before March 29, 1950 application; defect drawn to plaintiff's attention by November 20, 1948 application which sought to bar future amendments.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: O. XXI, r. 103 CPC; Kisandas Bupchand v. Rachappa Vithoba (tests: same relief without amendment? compensable by costs?)

petitioner_arguments.text: Amendment deprives appellant of limitation bar accrued by lapse of time.

respondent_arguments.text: Suit under O. XXI, r. 103 CPC; relief as per provision; amendment for further particulars does not alter nature of relief; mistake of pleader; substantial justice; compensate by costs.

court_reasoning.text: Appellate court has power to allow amendment; discretion exercised on correct principles; limitation expiry factor to consider but does not affect power if justice requires.
court_reasoning.key_observation: November 20, 1948 application made after limitation expired, sought to bar amendments; no surprise to appellant.

court_reasoning.text: Cites L.J. Leach: courts decline amendments if fresh suit barred, but factor in discretion; follows Charan Das: power exists, not exercise if takes away accrued right unless special circumstances.
Similar to Privy Council in Charan Das: amendment allowed despite limitation as no bad faith, no change in relief nature.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defect in plaint due to pleader's mistake.

court_reasoning.text: Rejects Kisandas tests as inflexible; amendment removes defect without changing quantity/quality of relief; no new case introduced.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ultimate test: no injustice if compensable by costs.

court_reasoning.text: Follows Batchelor J. in Kisandas: amendments allowed if no injustice and necessary for real controversy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant not taken by surprise; no new claim post-limitation.

holdings.text: High Court correctly exercised discretion in allowing amendment; no injustice to appellant as compensable by costs; amendment does not introduce new case or alter relief.

precedents_cited.case_name: L.J. Leach & Co. v. Jardine Skinner & Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Amendment power exists despite limitation bar if justice requires; factor in discretion.
Appellate power to amend even if deprives limitation defence unless special circumstances outweigh.
Tests by Beaman J. not inflexible; Batchelor J. principles apply: no injustice, necessary for real issues.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for execution resistance proceedings, suit for declaration of right to possession; limitation one year from r.99 order.

statutes_cited.name: Specific Relief Act, 1877
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogy in Privy Council case for amendment not altering relief nature.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave, upholding the Bombay High Court's order allowing amendment of the plaint at the appellate stage subject to costs, finding no error in exercise of discretion.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; amendment upheld for respondents.
outcome.costs: High Court imposed costs on plaintiff in favor of first defendant.

key_quotes.text: "We realise that by doing what we propose to do we may deprive the first defendant of a very valuable right which he claims he has acquired, namely, that of pleading a bar of limitation against the amended plaint, but we are guided more in this matter by regard to the principles of substantial justice"
key_quotes.speaker: high_court
key_quotes.significance: HC justification for amendment despite limitation.

key_quotes.text: "It is no doubt true that courts would, as a rule, decline to allow amendments, if a fresh suit on the amended claim would be barred by limitation on the date of the application. But that is a factor to be taken into account"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "All amendments ought to be allowed which satisfy the two conditions (a) of not working injustice to the other side, and (b) of being necessary for the purpose of determining the real questions in controversy"
key_quotes.speaker: court
